title: cops are led by donkeys sun says
story: Don’t get us wrong. This country is blessed to have hard-working frontline coppers doing their best to keep us safe.One of their number — PC Keith Palmer, who died in the Westminster Attack last year — will be rightly honoured with a memorial in the Parliament he gave his le to protect.But their bosses  The Home Office  It’s hard to shake the impression our lions are led by donkeys.Perceived hate crimes are deemed more important than burglaries and low-level violence. Top cops send their rank and file off to do PR stunts for the latest virtue-signalling cause. Every day seems to bring new tales of criminals getting away scot-free.It’s no surprise we’ve lost control of our streets, not just in the capital, but across the country — where kne crime is increasing at a HIGHER rate than in London.Politicians must do more than hope to plug the dam with a bit more cash. They must rebuild a ing force.That may well involve moving mental health responsibilities to another arm of government, or slashing the bureaucracy police are stuck with.It may even be time for an independent commission to look at policing.But this sorry state of affairs shames our nation — and leaves us all vulnerable.“AT the going down of the sun, and in the morning, we will remember them...”The lines of the famous war poem have never been as true as they are this weekend,  years on from the end of an awful conflict that took millions of lives. There are some who say that a century later we should consign this conflict to history. We respectfully disagree.We must keep on teaching the war’s horrors and of the reconciliation since. From a continent that tore itself apart twice in just four decades, Europe is now bound by common and friendly ties — no matter whether a country is an EU member or not.On Sunday that will be made abundantly clear when the German president lays a wreath at the Cenotaph.It is a fitting gesture of remembrance, and of progress.JO Johnson is entitled to his view that the PM’s Brexit deal is a bit of a mess.We share many of his concerns. Mrs May has a way to go to convince us she really is bringing us true independence.But his call for a second referendum is deeply dangerous. The people have had their say.They would not take kindly to being told to change their minds by the very political elites they turned against the first time.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: stop praying silence from charles
story: But close your eyes and imagine, for a moment, knowing from childhood exactly what job you are going to do — because you have no choice about whether or not you actually want to do it.And imagine, then, having to wait for that job to start until you are the age when most people are hanging up their work boots and starting to claim a pension.It’s impossible, right  But the Prince of Wales — the man who was born to be king — has known since the age of four that he would one day have to step into his mother’s shoes. And what a mother.They say no one is irreplaceable but I think she is — which must be such a lot of pressure for him. In short, he has spent his entire le waiting for his mum to die before he can start his dream job.And in the meantime his le, in some ways, is on hold. He was not allowed to marry the woman he loved and was instead forced into a loveless marriage.And every time he so much as expresses an opinion about anything, he is denounced as being “meddling”.So it’s no wonder that in Prince, Son And Heir, the BBC documentary this week marking his th birthday, Charles was quick to quell concerns that he would be a “meddling” or activist king, saying: “I’m not that stupid.”Declaring the role of sovereign and heir to be dferent, he said he is aware of the constraints he will encounter as king, and says his behaviour will change.I can see why he is saying that, given the amount of criticism that has come his way over the years. But when you think that he was campaigning about issues such as the environment and single-use plastic long before anyone  got on the bandwagon, it might be better to see him as a trailblazer than a meddler.I admire that he has a voice.And when he is king I think he should use it — not be silenced by the pressure of the role.He has a very broad range of knowledge and he is absolutely passionate. We live in a society where everyone has their say — so why shouldn’t he In fact, I thinkhe visited Europe he might help with Brexit.There is no doubt the Queen is a hard act to follow — when the time comes, that is. Now Charles is  he is the longest serving heir to the throne in history. And he may have years to go, as the Queen looks and sounds fantastic .But we should stop maligning Charles and start supporting him.He is a good man and there is no doubt he is dedicated to the job. He is mature enough to know how to do the job well and he certainly knows what is expected of him.He has brought up two fantastic sons that any parent would be proud of.And he really is passionate about changing the world for the better.It has been more than  years since he set up his Prince’s Trust charity.Last year alone it helped nearly , young people get into education, training and jobs. It is simply fantastic.He is deeply committed to his fantastic we, who is very down-to-earth and great fun .He is also passionate about promoting women’s issues, so whatever you think of him you must give him credit for that.I believe very strongly in the monarchy. I would do anything the Queen asked me to do.The Royal Family are a great thing for our country and something to be very proud of.In a world of increasing uncertainty, they are this country’s rock and foundation. We should all get behind Charles and celebrate him as our future king.Apart from anything , we need all the stability we can get. ANYONE living in London will be unsurprised to hear that there are now a record number of people sleeping rough there.Figures show there were , rough sleepers in the capital between July and September – the first time the total has exceeded , in a three-month period.It’s awful and it’s shocking to see people sitting in the cold begging for money.And it’s hard to know how to help. Of course, the temptation is to give money but obviously that’s just a short-term fix.Night shelters are a good short-term solution. Buthomeless people don’t get involved with a network that can really help them, it’s unlikely their circumstances will ever change.My husband Paul volunteers with the fantastic charity West London Mission . It offers homeless people a hot shower, new clothes, a meal and a decent night’s sleep.But it also offers access to project workers who will help people change their circumstances.Its aim is to empower and help homeless people become part of a community, because that’s the start of them getting off the streets, into accommodation, then into work.There are so many reasons that people become homeless. Some have lost their job and can’t afford rent, or they’ve fallen out with family and turn to drink and drugs.They might have mental or physical health problems, a history of abuse or a dficult childhood moving between foster homes.But where there is le, there is hope. Paul has been working with one guy who was homeless and hopelessly addicted to drugs.But, over time, he has got clean, found a place to live and, last week, got a job at a restaurant, which is what he was doing before he got involved in drugs.He’s got his le back, basically. It does happen.Soyou are worried about homelessness, think about donating to an organisation such as WLM. Better yet, volunteer your time and skills.Even just helping someone to fill out a form, which can be incredibly dficult for some people, can make a huge dference and is so rewarding.TODAY is Remembrance Day and I wear my poppy with pride. This year I will particularly recognise all the true heroes from World War One. I thank them for their service, and remember we are always in their debt.It is so important we never forget the sacrice they made and the bravery they showed.I doubt there will ever be another generation like them. AS a rule, I like to live and let live. title: apprentice airline best episode years
story: It split apart million years ago and, must confess, it had entirely escaped my notice before Wednesday night — when it became the fourth-worst ever suggestion for the name of an airline, behind Black Box, Crash Positions and Ryanair.Or it was until Sabrina, from team Collaborative, came up with something that was worse than all of them — Jet Pop Airlines — and added a little explosion in the logo, just to set passengers’ minds fully at rest.No one involved should beat themselves up over any of these decisions, though, as they helped create the best episode of The Apprentice in years.It probably needed to be, as well. I sense, like the recently axed Big Brother and The X Factor, it’s been living off its reputation for a couple of years.Enjoyable as it’s been, the basic issue with this run has been the lack of a central figure in the mould of Syed Ahmed, Katie Hopkins or the late, great Stuart Baggs to take the series by the scruff of the neck.Some have shown vague promise but the closest thing it’s had to an alpha bell-end is Captain Pangea himself, Kurran Pooni, who was marked out less by his all-round uselessness than by the wrist he broke arm-wrestling back at the house, and his insistence he was “ per cent stepping up as project manager” just before he  per cent stepped down.There was no dodging the bullet, though, last week, when Lord Sugar demanded he PM a marketing campaign “for a noo airline” with accompanying adverts “and a noo unorm as well”.Kurran wasn’t underselling the sense of destiny he felt at this responsibility. “Everything in my le has led to this moment,” he claimed, presumably ’cos he hadn’t done anything  up until that moment.The great thing about this task, though — like all the best Apprentice episodes — was that the laughs were shared round equally.So while advert director Kurran was recreating the Club Tropicana video on Southend seafront, Camilla and Jackie were designing a stewardess’s unorm for the party-themed Jet Pop that wouldn’t see the light of day eveneasyJet suddenly opened a brothel chain in Amsterdam.A horrible thought occurred, though, as she was market-researching at Heathrow.She’s not going to wear that thing pitching to  industry experts at BA HQ, is she  She bloody is, you know.She gave it the full doors-to-manual flirtation as well. So everyone’s mind was already in the gutter before Jackie finished the audience off with the news: “It’s very easy to wipe down, as well.”In the normal course of events, reducing Claude Littner to a helpless giggling wreck would be enough to lose any task.The other team, though, Typhoon, had contrived to come up with something almost as bad, Manage Air, a business-targeted operation whose corporate logo looked like a satanic pentangle and theme tune was AC DC’s Highway To Hell.There was a genuine sense of tension in the boardroom then, which would’ve been ruinedSugar had played it all for laughs.He didn’t, though. He let the contestants hang themselves with their own words before firing Kurran, who could leave with a sense of “job done”.He’s created a bit of Apprentice folklore, after all, and hopefully reminded everyone this show is far from dead.Naturally, in the final taxi scene, he also remained convinced of his genius, boldly declaring: “My advert was gold.”The first and possibly last time in his le where he’s not just  per cent wrong, he’s  per cent right as well.Glorious television.Dianne: “Stephen Fry.”The Time It Takes, Joe Lycett: “Sesame Street’s Big Bird lives in what street ”Oliver: “I don’t know.”Joe Lycett: “A bird in the hand is worth two in the what ”Jon: “Foot.”And Bradley Walsh: “Which former EastEnders star presents the Sky One series Extreme World ”Zoe: “Barbara Windsor.”CELEBRITY Hunted contestant and former Commando Johnny Mercer MP has faced a stark choice this past month.The eternal humiliation of being beaten by Chris and Kem, off Love Island, on the Channel  hide ’n’ seek game.Or two weeks in a confined space with a clearly smitten Kay Burley.Heroically, he chose the latter, enduring her attention and pet namewith the same sort of grit that probably saw him through three tours of Afghanistan.Then, last week, he sneaked off for an unscheduled visit to his we, Felicity, and Burley completely lost her s***.Lost it so badly, in fact, that she threw herself at the mercy of a passing bread truck driver, which led to the best update of the series: “Kay Burley is currently in a -ton lorry, on the M, between junction  and .”She was quickly grassed up, of course, then apprehended at the Warburton’s depot, without the need for a vet or a tranquilliser dart.But while it’s a poorer show without the old mad-whack, there’s still plenty of mileage left in this gripping series.AJ Pritchard is cornered in Shropshire, Olympic silver medallist Louis Smith has just been found hiding in his mate’s Jacuzzi showroomand Baldrick-brained duo Chris  Kemhave somehow given everyone the slip.But as for Johnny Mercer  He’s probably smuggling himself back to the Mouth of Hell fort, in southern Helmand, just for the relative peace and quiet. Paul Merson: “For me it’s six and a half of one and a dozen of the other.”Graeme Souness: “The only one with potential is Martial and Pogba.”Dion Dublin: “Liverpool are in second and a half gear.”And Charlie Nicholas: “Pogba’s either brilliant or a showpony. He played OK last week.”THIS week’s Doctor Who episode introduced us to the Demons Of The Punjab, who turned out to be nothing of the sort.They were just morbid sods who mope around the universe “honouring those who die alone”, like soldiers, holy men and Brendan O’Carroll on For Facts Sakes.No actual science-fiction storyline to speak of then.But that’s not really the point of this viewer-shedding series, which has already got on its high horse about sexism, Donald Trump, American segregationist racism, men giving birth and gun control.Kind of inevitable, then, that the BBC would eventually pour a bucket of its self-loathing sick all over the British Empire, via the partition of India in , with an episode that was every bit as historically powerful as Carry On Up The Khyber.The key dference, of course, was that Bungdit Din and his Burpers weren’t actually being used as a means of brainwashing children.Because If you were expecting Doctor Who to present the flip side of Britain’s relatively benign rule in India , then you’ll also be waiting for the episode where Jodie Whittaker lands in a Soviet gulag and starts teaching children about the brutal idiocy of Marxism.The BBC just doesn’t do anything other than its own left-of-centre view, these days – or irony by the sounds of things.As it’s just been revealed there’ll be no festive episode of Doctor Whobecause it’s “run out” of storylines.Run out  RUN OUT How the hell can a series run out of ideas when it hasn’t had any yet This Morning, Thursday: “Coming up, at quarter to , the rise of the penis filler, Doctor Ranj is here to answer your questions.”The show’s other penis filler, Martin Lewis, will answer them on Monday.IT seems almost wrong to single out just one programme from Sunday’s beautul Armistice Day coverage, but the year’s most meaningful TV awards should probably all go to BBC’s They Shall Not Grow Old, made by Peter Jackson, whose astonishing film gave a voice, laughter, tears and colour to some of the extraordinary men who survived the - trenches.Those of us who watched it, on Sunday, are unlikely ever to forget the experience. Those of you who didn’t, must catch up with it on the BBC iPlayer.Be sure, though, to watch it right through to the credits’ last chorus of Mademoiselle From Armentières, where it names the veterans who have all long since passed but whose memories and souls have never seemed more alive and unforgettable.“It’s quite hard to put your finger on it.”I’ll bet.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: google virtual tour lets royal fans look around prince charles homes clarence house and highgrove
story: To mark Charles th birthday the web giant has made his official London residence Clarence House and country retreat of Highgrove - as well as the green spaces he has spent almost  years through Clarence House and the personal collection of His Royal Highness and the royal family.She added: Now using -degree imagery anyone can stroll down the halls, explore the art collection, go from one room to another and really come up close with a lot of the artworks.In one section of the Google Arts and Culture website, Charles le is told in pictures and video while another focuses on the work of his Afghanistan-based organisation Turquoise Mountain, which is restoring historic buildings in Kabul.Images available include black-and-white footage of a toddler prince at play, a sequence of pictures showing the Duke of Sussex fishing with his father, and the official wedding photographs of Harry and Meghans royal nuptials and the Duke and Duchess of Cambridges big day.The new pages of Mothers former Scottish home the Castle of Mey, while the other two are paintings of crofts, or rural homes, on the island of Stroma north of John OGroats.The watercolours are accompanied by photographs of the prince painting, sat in a canvas chair with the Castle of Mey in the distance, or wearing sunglasses with a pencil in his hand and a pad on his lap.The prince learned about Google Arts and Culture after visiting the firms offices in London in May, and soon afterwards his household began working with the search engine.Google Arts and Culture began in  and collaborates with museums and other institutions to use technology to bring heritage and artwork to an online audience.Julian Payne, Charles communications secretary, said the heir to the throne had been keeping a close eye on the project.He added: I have to say the prince was fascinated by the opportunity that arts and culture provides to connect people to museums, other cultural institutions and provide title: postman eats mcdonalds month weight loss
story: Ryan Williams, , launched his fast food mission to disprove filmmaker Morgan Spurlocks famous Super Size Me documentary.In , the American filmmaker gorged on Mc Donalds for  days and gained two stone, chomping through , calories per day.But Ryan from Cheltenham, Glos., pointed out that he was doing no exercise during the challenge.Ryan spent between £-£ each day for a month on McDonalds and made sure to eat everything on their menu at least once, as Spurlock did  years ago.But the buff postie also spent an hour at the gym each morning during his challenge in October.And he finished the month one stone two lbs lighter than when he began, having lost just over two percent of his body fat.Ryan documented the challenge daily on his YouTube channel Ry, where he has built up a following of over , people who frequently watch him eating quirky things.He said: Ive wanted to do this for a few years, but I never found the right time.But recently I saw an advert for  years of Big Mac, and it made me think that theres quite a lot of negative feeling towards McDonalds, with regards to it being unhealthy.Ever since I saw Super Size Me, I thought that the way hedid the experiment, was unfair.He ate , calories a day and didnt do any exercise, I didnt feel like it was a surprise he became so unhealthy.Ryan added: Its obvious that calories are quite important, but the average Joe doesnt always know how to balance the recommended calorie intake with staying in shape.Im not suggesting that eating just McDonalds is a healthy way of living, but I wanted to show that its purely a calorie game, as opposed to the types of food you eat.But Ryan, who started the month weighing  stone and lbs, said it was all about sticking within the recommended calorie intake and maintaining a frequent exercise programme.He began the month eating , calories per day - the recommended calorie intake for a male adult - but dropped down to , by the end of the second week.And in the final two weeks of the challenge, he dropped his calories slightly further, depending on how his weight and body fat index was performing.In the same format as the original programme, he made it a rule to eat everything off the menu at least once - from Big Macs and McFlurrys to salad boxes and bags of fruit.Ryan said: Prior to the challenge I was probably in the worst state Id been in in a few years.My diet wasnt great, I would eat a lot of food - about , calories - in a day, lots of biscuits and junk food, and I wasnt going to the gym at all.Before that, for about  years, I was always very active and went to the gym four or five times a week.So for me, this challenge was partly about what I could do to help myself get back to that, whilst also having a bit of fun.By the end of his challenge, Ryan was down to  stone and had gone from . per cent body fat during a seven-site skinfold test, down to . per cent.Ryan said he switched up his eating habits halfway through the month, going from eating three meals a day in the first  days, to consuming all his calories for the day in one go.He said: On a couple of days I would eat only one item off the menu - so, for instance, I would live on just Big Macs for a day, or just McFlurrys for a day.I just hope that people see this and see the lightheartedness in it, and learn to worry less about the types of food they eat.

title: film maker ammonia throat gang woman trap
story: Courtney Raymond, , and Jordan Dubois, , were attacked as they went to a flat in Argyle Road, Ilford, to make a video for a song called Creepy.Makayla Hajaig, , greeted them outside on June  but said her sister, a singer called Stafia, was inside putting on her make-up, jurors heard.She led them inside and they were pounced on by Adam Badejo, , William Deo, , said Nathan Rasiah, prosecuting.Mr Raymond was knocked to the floor and a third man, wearing a balaclava, poured ammonia down his throat, Snaresbrook Crown Court heard.Stafia exists but has no involvement in this case. Her identity was used for the purpose of setting the ambush, said Mr Rasiah.On  May, Hajaig used an Instagram account to contact Courtney Raymond.Raymond and Dubois were later sent a song by email with the subject Creepy MP.Mr Rasiah said: On  June the defendants arrived at Argyle Road together. The men went into the property and laid in wait.Courtney Raymond and Jordan Dubois arrived at the scene and were met by a young woman. She told them it was her sister who contacted them, and she was upstairs getting her make-up done.The three of them went into the property together with Jordan Dubois carrying his equipment in an Adidas rucksack.Makayla Hajaig led them in saying the flat belonged to her sisters family.Mr Raymond recalls two or three men running at them from upstairs and a large figure with a balaclava coming towards him with a bottle, said Mr Rasiah.They both recall him squirting a liquid in their faces. Mr Raymond believed it was acid, but it was in fact ammonia.Mr Raymond and Mr Dubois were told to hand over their bags containing cameras and lighting equipment worth over £,, jurors heard.Mr Raymond was punched in the stomach, his knees gave way, but he was forced to get up and open his mouth, said the prosecutor.One of the figures poured the liquid down his throat and it started to burn.Mr Raymond and Mr Dubois managed to get away and staggered to the home of neighbour Damien Butler who began pouring water over their faces.Both Courtney Raymond and Jordan Dubois were taken to hospital around about :pm, said Mr Rasiah.Mr Raymond was seen to in the AE department at Queens Hospital and he was sedated and placed in a medically induced coma and he remained in intensive care for some  days until  June.There were attempts to examine his airways which had to be abandoned because they revealed swelling.Both Courtney Raymond and Jordan Dubois had their vision impaired by ammonia.The prosecutor said Badejo, Deo, and Hajaig were caught on CCTV at a Turkish eatery called Gokyuzq shortly after the attack.Deo was arrested as he left the £ per-night Redmond hotel in Archway for a taxi to take him to Southampton.He had dyed his dark brown hair to a bright ginger colour, it was said.Badejo, of Keppel Road, Dagenham, Deo of Bobbington Close, Archway, north London, and Hajaig of Valence Wood Road, Dagenham, all deny two charges of throwing a corrosive substance, two charges of robbery, one charge of causing grievous bodily harm and one of assault occasioning actual bodily harm.Hajaig alone denies a further charge of assisting an offender.The trial continues.

story: Furious bike users have slammed the decision to install the four digital signs along the seven-mile prom in Bournemouth, Dorset.Nicole Nagel, who founded Bournemouth Cycling Without Age, accused Bournemouth Borough Council of being totally anti-cycling.Im from Germany where a lot is done for cyclists but Ive lived here  years and its very very dangerous for cyclists, he told The MailOnline.They could have used that money to build a proper cycle lane - especially for children, to cross the road safely on bikes, something to make it more appealing to use bikes, rather than putting speed cameras up.The move came after concerns grew over safety on the promenade. Last year a -year-old grandmother was left badly hurt after she was mown down by a cyclist doing mph.And two months later a five-year-old boy was left with cuts and bruises after being hit by a speeding cyclist.The £,-a-piece vehicle activated signs flash up the speed limit of mph to warn offending riders they are going too fast.They come in addition to existing signage that reminds cyclists of the mph speed list and that pedestrians have the right of way.Three of them have been paid for by the Bournemouth Borough Council, while the fourth is funded by beach hut owners fed up with cyclists flying past their cabins.She added that there had been a lot of near misses, especially with holiday-makers, and hopes that the signs will encourage people to slow down.In addition to the signs, there is a total ban on cycling during July and August, when Bournemouth beach is packed with up to , visitors a day.

title: john f kennedy age marriage jackie bouvier presidency
story: Let’s take a look at the youngest US leader in history.John Fitzgerald Kennedy, the th President of the United States, was born on May , , in Massachusetts.He was assassinated on June , , when he was -years-old.His family were wealthy Irish-Americans while his father Joseph was a leading figure in the Democratic Party and served as US Ambassador to the UK.Johns mother Rose, whose dad was the mayor of Boston, had nine children - three of which had prominent careers in frontline politics.JFK was educated at Hard University graduating in  before serving in the US navy during World War II.Following the war, John entered politics in  spurred on by his father Joseph and was elected to the US House of Representatives – the lower chamber of Congress.He became a Democratic Senator in .His meteoric rise within the Democrats was cemented in  when he won the party’s nomination for president.Johns youthful good looks and charisma ensured that he defeated Republican candidate Richard Nixon in the general election.Aged , he became the youngest US President in history and first Catholic to hold the office.His brother Robert and Edward, known as Ted, also had distinguished careers in US politics.Ted served as a Senator from  until his death in  while Robert was Attorney General from  until .Robert was tragically assassinated on June , , during his primary campaign for the Democratic nomination for president.He was shot and killed by -year-old Palestinian Sirhan Sirhan who was motivated by Kennedy’s support for Israel.Jackie Kennedy, formerly Jacqueline Lee Bouvier, married John on September , .The pair wed at St Marys Church in Newport, Rhode Island, and they had  guests at the ceremony alone.In the reception that followed, , guests made their way to Hammersmith Farm and the wedding was considered the social event of the season.The newlyweds honeymooned in Acapulco, Mexico, before settling in, Hickory Hill, Virginia.Jackie was First Lady of the United States from - after her husband was elected as US President.In later years it emerged that John had numerous affairs with other women while married to Jackie.Together, the couple had four children Caroline Kennedy, John F. Kennedy Jr, Patrick Bouvier Kennedy, Arabella Kennedy.Patrick died when he was just two days old and Arabella was stillborn.Jackie was in the car with her husband JFK in Dallas, Texas, when he was assassinated.After his funeral, she and her children withdrew from public view and moved to New York City.She married Greek shipping magnate Aristotle Onassis in  before she was widowed again in .Her son JFK Jr was killed in a place crash in .John was inaugurated on January , , and was assassinated on November , .His time in office was dominated by America’s Cold War tensions with the Soviet Union.He also introduced domestic reforms including expanding the civil rights of African Americans.In April , he launched the unsuccessful Bay of Pigs invasion of Cuba using anti-communist Cuban exiles.Many historians believe that President Kennedy’s failure to overthrow Fidel Castro’s regime made him appear weak to the Soviets and prompted Moscow to install nuclear weapons in Cuba.This sparked the infamous Cuban missile crisis which brought the world to the brink of nuclear war.Following a stand off which lasted nearly two weeks, Soviet leader Nikita Kruschev withdrew the atomic missiles from Cuba.Kennedy was assassinated in Dallas as he travelled in a motorcade through Dealey Plaza.Shortly after, Lee Harvey Oswald, a -year-old self-proclaimed Marxist, was arrested in a nearby cinema after police hunted a killer of one of their fellow officers.He denied shooting anybody, claiming to reporters that he was a patsy.Later Oswald was accused of shooting the President dead with his  mail-order rle from a window of the sixth floor of a nearby school textbook warehouse.Two days after the assassination and his arrest, Oswald was being escorted from Dallas Police Headquarters to county prison.As he was paraded in front of the world’s media, a man called Jack Ruby stepped forward and shot him dead.Ruby, who had mob connections, was later found guilty of murder and sentenced to death.He appealed but died of an illness in jail in  before his new trial could take place.The official probe into Kennedys killing, known as the Warren Commission, reported in  that Oswald had been the lone gunman.Another congressional probe in  found no evidence to support the theory that the CIA had been involved despite numerous conspiracy theories around the assassination.Theories include a CIA plot, a mafia hit job and a covert operation by the vice president Lyndon Johnson.

title: eu army emmanuel macron angela merkel latest
story: Merkel declared there should be an integrated European Union military, recalling the lessons of the First World War and the isions that led to the conflict.Speaking to MEPs today about the future of Europe, Merkel said the continent should take its fate fully into its own hands.Echoing comments made by French leader Emmanuel Macron last week, she said: We should work on a vision of one day establishing a real, true European army.Merkel added that such an army would not undermine the US-led military alliance NATO but could be complementary to it. It should include common development of arms industry, she said as well as an EU-wide arms export policy and crucially a European intervention force.It came a day after a senior minister from the French Government called for the EU to become a powerful new “empire” to rival the US and China in an interview which will infuriate Donald Trump.Merkels remarks today in the EU parliament drew loud applause in the legislature but also boos from euro-sceptic members.One of them was chief Brexiteer Nigel Farage, who said: Its a European Union that we are told is now to become an empire - a militarised European Union.A European Union that has launched a new Cold against the United States of America.One hundreds years on from the Armistice we should genuinely be worried.The idea that this new militarised union is somehow a recipe for peace I suggest you sit back and think a little bit more carefully.Maybe you should all re-read history because the European project was set up to stop German domination and what you have seen today is a naked take-over bid.Yesterday French finance minister Bruno Le Maire said Europe must be strong enough to defend itself in the future - words the US president called insulting.Le Maire controversial calls for a new superstate came as he backed Macron’s and Merkels plan for a “real European army”.Le Maire suggested Brussels should go one even further and establish itself as an “empire”.Its about Europe having to become a kind of Empire, as China is. And how the US is, the French finance minister told the German newspaper Handelsblatt.After being quizzed by the newspaper on his comments, he added: “Do not get me wrong, Im talking about a peaceful empire thats a constitutional state.I use the term to raise awareness that the world of tomorrow will be about power.Power will make a dference: technological power, economic, financial, monetary, cultural power will be crucial.Trump has blasted Macrons idea for the European Union to build an army to protect itself from the US as insulting.The US President tweeted: President Macron of France has just suggested that Europe build its own military in order to protect itself from the US, China and Russia.Very insulting, but perhaps Europe should first pay its fair share of NATO, which the US subsidises greatly!It comes three days after the French President said the US is as big a threat to the EU as Russia and China and called for a “true European army” to defend the bloc.In an extraordinary attack on the US president, Macron lumped Washington together with Moscow and Beijing as Europe’s biggest foes.The arch euro federalist insisted only a fully fledged EU defence force can protect the continent against the trio’s aggression.He said: “We have to protect ourselves with respect to China, Russia and even the United States of America.“We will not protect the Europeans unless we decide to have a true European army.”The French president lashed Mr Trump for deciding to pull the US out of a nuclear treaty with Russia that was signed during the Cold War.He raged: “When I see President Trump announcing that he’s quitting a major disarmament treaty which was formed after the s euro-missile crisis that hit Europe, who is the main victim  Europe and its security.”Mr Macron made the comments in a radio interview from the town of Verdun - the site of a major WW battle - as he tours the Western Front ahead of Remembrance Day.They were welcomed by the EU Commission, which said it has already put the wheels in motion for the eventual creation of a euro army.A spokesman beamed: “If there is a Commission that has put forward the need for a meaningful defence identity for the EU, it’s this Commission.“President Macron has been consistently putting forward this narrative for a stronger Europe that empowers and protects.“This is totally totally compatible with our work and all contributions from our EU leaders, and especially from President Macron, are very much welcome.”But the remarks were savaged by former British Army commanders, who said the revelations showed why the UK must pull out of the EU’s defence plans.Major General Julian Thompson, who led British forces in the Falklands, told The Sun: “The EU Commission now openly admits it has created the preamble to an EU army.The UK is in that preamble and risks being kept in it.“Ministers must withdraw or risk losing forever whole chunks of the UK’s democratic control over defence.”Colonel Richard Kemp, a commander of UK troops in Afghanistan, added: “This is precisely what eurosceptics have been warning about.“It is time for ministers now to take notice and rein in what they have agreed since the referendum.They have been led astray in the most crucial area of sovereignty.”And Tory MEP Geoffrey Van Orden, a former British Army Brigadier, raged: “Instead of th century dreams of French-led European grandeur, President Macron should be helping build Western solidarity.“That means helping and not obstructing a strong partnership with Britain and strengthening the NATO alliance.”

title: brits wont need a visa to travel to europe even if we get a no deal brexit eu confirms
story: UK citizens will be able to visit the EU for up to three months at a time without having to get new documents - eventhere is a No Deal Brexit.The European Commission today unveiled plans for a new visa regime after Britain leaves the EU in March next year.Eurocrats said: The European Commission has today proposed to grant UK citizens visa-free travel to the EU after the United Kingdoms withdrawal from the European Union.It would mean that UK citizens would not need a visa when travelling to the Schengen area for short stays of up to  days in any -day period.Brits who want to work in Europe, or visit for more than three months, may still need to get a visa.And holidaymakers wont be able to use the fast lane at passport control - meaning there could be much longer queues for British people at European airports.The commission also warned that under a No Deal scenario, British driving licences and pet passports could be useless on the continent.The new regime will come into force in four monthsBritain ends up crashing out of the EU without a withdrawal deal.Butwe do get a deal, it will only apply after the end of the transition period which will conclude in December .The EU said that the offer of visa-free travel will be withdrawnthe UK refuses to let Europeans come in without a visa.Theresa May has already promised not to impose visas on holidaymakers from Europe.But it was previously feared the EU would charge Brits £ or more for a permit to enter after Brexit.Todays announcement applies to all the countries of the EU except Ireland, plus Norway, Switzerland, Iceland and Liechtenstein.Freedom of movement between the UK and Ireland is already guaranteed under a separate treaty dating back to .A Government spokesman said: A UK government spokesperson said: We welcome the proposal by the European Commission which reflects the future relationship that the UK wants with the rest of the EU.We have been clear in our proposals that we want to ensure reciprocal measures on visa-free travel for tourists and short term business visitors with the EU.”Anti-Brexit campaigners claimed the new rules will hurt British citizens who spent large parts of the year abroad.Lib Dem MP Tom Brake said: This will come as a real shock to those who spend their winter months in Spain or Portugal and will now see additional costs and potential queues providing extra baggage.

title: first traffic light invented j p knight
story: Let’s take a look at inventor J.P Knight and his landmark invention.Mr Knight came up with the idea for traffic lights after more than  people died in road accidents in London in .While motor cars did not hit the streets of the UK until later in the th century, Knight’s system was put in place to regulate horse-drawn carriages.The world’s first traffic lights were installed outside the Houses of Parliament near Westminster Bridge in .Knight based the system on railway signal lights.They used waving semaphore arms operated by a policeman during the day and featured red and green gas-operated lamps for use at night time.However, the gas lamp exploded and killed a policeman in  resulting in the lights being removed.Modern traffic lights using the red-green lights system were first installed in Cleveland in .The three colour signals favoured by many countries, including the UK, were first used in New York in .In fact, it was not until  when the next set of lights appeared in Britain turning up in the busy junction between St Jamess Street and Piccadilly in London.These were operated manually by policeman. Automatic lights operating on a time interval became common in .John Peake Knight was born on December , , in Nottingham.He left Nottingham High School aged  and worked in the parcel room at Derby railway station.Knight enjoyed a successful career in UK railways and aged  was promoted to Traffic Manager of the London to Brighton line.He is credited with improving the quality of rail travel in Britain - installing safe carriages and alarm pulls for women.Knight and his we Elizabeth had five sons.The inventor died in  and was buried in Londons Brompton Cemetery.

title: brexit deal theresa may eu refuses compromise
story: The PM has summoned the Cabinet to Downing Street to sign off on the details of the withdrawal agreement.Britain and the EU reached the deal after days of round-the-clock talks in Brussels.The PM is seeing her senior ministers one by one throughout this evening - before an emergency Cabinet meeting to be held tomorrow.Details of the proposed agreement have not yet been made public and are likely to be revealed later this week.Mrs May is keen to win over sceptical Brexiteers who worry that her plan will leave Britain tied to the EU customs union permanently.Pro-Brexit ministers have privately threatened to resign rather than sign up to a deal they dont like.Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab, Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey and Commons Leader Andrea Leadsom are seen as the big beasts most likely to walk out.If the Cabinet signs off on the deal, the EU is set to hold an emergency summit in two or three weeks, where all  European leaders will approve it.Mrs Mays spokesman said earlier today: The Prime Minister told Cabinet that since it had last met negotiations had continued in Brussels and good progress had been made.However, the PM said there remained a small number of outstanding issues as the UK pushes for the best text that can be negotiated.Officials had another late night in Brussels and restarted their talks early in the morning, he added.Last night the PM vowed to hold firm in the final round of negotiations and insisted leaving without a deal would be better than selling out to Brussels.Speaking at the Lord Mayors banquet in London, she promised not to let Brexit voters down by signing up to a deal which doesnt deliver on the  referendum.Mrs May said: The negotiations for our departure are now in the endgame.And we are working extremely hard, through the night, to make progress on the remaining issues in the Withdrawal Agreement, which are signicant.Both sides want to reach an agreement. But what we are negotiating is immensely dficult.Overwhelmingly, the British people want us to get on with delivering Brexit, and I am determined to deliver for them.I want them to know that I will not compromise on what people voted for in the referendum.This will not be an agreement at any cost. Any deal must ensure we take back control of our laws, borders and money.It must secure the ability to strike new trade deals around the world. And it must also be a deal that protects jobs, our security and our precious Union.David Lidington, the Cabinet Office Minister who is Mrs Mays de facto deputy, said it was still possible but not at all definite that a deal would be struck a day or two.He told the BBC: Weve managed to get things down to a small number of dficult issues which are still outstanding.This was always going to be an extremely dficult, extremely complex negotiation but we are almost within touching distance now.The PM is today confronting her senior ministers at a Cabinet meeting.Leading Brexiteers are pushing Mrs May to walk away from talks with Brusselsthe EU refuses to be flexible on the tricky question of the Irish backstop.And in another sign of trouble for the PM, Labour MP Kate Hoey - one of the partys few Brexit backers - today said she wont vote for the dealit panders to the Republic of Ireland.The backstop is meant to ensure the Irish border stays open no matter what happens in future trade talks.But some Brexiteers are worried the EU is trying to keep Britain tied to the customs union permanently.

title: angela merkel confirms brexiteers worst
story: NewsAngela Merkel confirms Brexiteers worst fears by backing European ArmyThe German Chancellor joined French President Emmanuel Macrons call for a "common European Army"ShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editor:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsIts one of Brexiteers worst fears "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAngela Merkel yesterday backed Emmanuel Macron’s call for a European Army. The German Chancellor risked provoking Donald Trump after supporting the French President’s plans for a continent-wide defence force. She told MEPs in Strasbourg: “We should work on a vision of one day establishing a real European army.” Mrs Merkel, who joined Mr Macron for emotional First World War centenary commemorations last weekend, said the new force would not replace NATO, which includes the US. “A common European army would show the world that there will never be war again in Europe. We can be a good supplement to NATO,” she added. The UK has long opposed a European army. But some EU leaders see Brexit as a chance to finally create an EU force without Britain’s opposition.  Mr Macron riled his American counterpart after calling for the EU to create its own army, “to protect us against China, Russia and even the United States of America.” In the interview with French radio station Europe  the French leader mentioned “re-emerging authoritarian powers” that were well-armed on Europe’s borders, “attempted attacks in cyberspace and interference in our democratic lives”, concluding: “We have to protect ourselves with respect to China, Russia and even the United States of America.” Hitting back as his Air Force One jet touched down in Paris, Mr Trump hit back in a tweet: “President Macron of France has just suggested that Europe build its own military in order to protect itself from the US, China and Russia. There were . million EU nationals working in the UK from July to September, , fewer than a year earlier. The Office for National Statistics said this was the largest yearly fall since records began in . ONS experts tried to calm talk of a Brexodus - stressing that the estimates do not measure flows of recent migrants to the UK.Jonathan Portes, professor of economics at Kings College London, pointed the finger at Brexit and warned of signicant negative impacts for the NHS and social care.The prospect of Brexit has clearly made the UK a much less attractive place for Europeans to live and work, he declared.  The Resolution Foundation think tank warned the figures show Britains labour market is already changing ahead of Brexit day on  March . Expert Stephen Clarke said: Firms who employ a large share of migrant workers need to think now about adjusting to a lower migration environment, in terms of the workers they employ, what they produce and how they operate. A sharp drop has been fuelled by a decrease from eight east European countries that joined the EU in . The figures show , of the EU workers employed in the UK in the latest quarter were citizens of the so-called EUA states, Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, Slovakia and Slovenia. This was , fewer than in the equivalent period of last year.  The number of EUA employees is down by , compared with July-September , just after the EU referendum, when it stood at a record level of more than a million. It came despite a rise in the number of workers from the rest of the world. There were . million non-EU nationals working in the UK in July to September, , more than  months earlier. And the drop was not reflected in  other EU states. There were , nationals of  long-term EU member states including Germany, Italy, Spain and France working in the UK, a slight increase on , a year earlier. Ministers are preparing to finally unveil proposals for the post-Brexit immigration regime before the end of the year.  A white paper is expected to set out plans for a system which brings an end to free movement and prioritises higher-skilled workers. But Lib Dem MP Ed Davey claimed: Even before we’ve left the EU, we’re seeing a Brexodus that is bad for British businesses and especially bad for our public services. Alp Mehmet, vice chairman of Migration Watch UK, said the figures were good news. Todays figures showed both unemployment and employment are on the rise. Unemployment has increased by , to .million but employment also rose by ,, to a record high of .million. ONS senior statistician Matt Hughes said: The labour market is little changed on the previous three months, though still stronger than it was at this time last year. With faster wage growth and more subdued inflation, real earnings have picked up noticeably in the last few months. However, real wage growth is below the level seen in , and real wages have not yet ed to their  levels. The recent uptick in British nationals in work and the decline in workers from the so-called A Eastern European countries both seem to be accelerating.

title: brexit could force time zones
story: NewsBrexit could force time zones to be dferent in Northern Ireland and the RepublicThe EU wants to ban daylight savings time - and the UK doesnt. MPs fear that could leave Northern Ireland and the Republic one hour apartShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsBrexit is going to be a race against time - in more ways than one "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Northern Ireland and the Republic could end up in dferent TIME ZONES after Brexit , the House of Commons has heard.A Tory minister did not rule out the bizarre situation happening when we leave - despite attempts to stop any friction along the -mile border. The EU is trying to ban daylight savings time across the bloc. But the UK wants to carry on moving its clocks forward to British Summer Timeevery spring. During a Commons debate yesterday, Business Minister Kelly Tolhurst was askedNorthern Ireland and the Republic could end up one hour apart.  She did not rule it out, instead saying: At the moment this is why were having this debate We are as a United Kingdom... working with other member states. We are joined with others who are against this proposal. And there are some other member states who have yet to give their firm position on whether they want to accept or not this proposal. So of course the time zone is a reserve for Great Britain.  And we would obviouslywe were ever in a position where we would need to change clocks, we would consult widely before any decision was made in the United Kingdom.Labour MP Stella Creasy warned there was a very real risk thatshes not successful, they could face dferent time zones across that border.And Labour MP Darren Jones tweeted: Minister not sure what this will mean for dferent time in Northern Ireland compared to Ireland. #BrexitShambles October : No Deal preparations have to begin no matter what, because otherwise they wont be ready on time. November : The UK was hoping for a final Brexit summit to seal not just a deal, but a political declaration on future trade. However, this looked off the cards as talks stalled over the Northern Irish border. - December : The next scheduled European Council summit. This is the last chance saloon to get a deal. Already its much later than was ideal. Otherwise there wont be time to sign it off before Brexit Day. After a deal is reached: MPs hold a vote on any deal in Parliament. This is danger moment two for Theresa May, who will likely face a Tory leadership challengeshe loses the vote. She claims the UK will leave with No Deal anywayshe loses. But Labour say she should be forced back to the negotiating table call a general election or even trigger a second EU referendum.  March : Brexit Day. If theres a deal, this will be a total anticlimax because a transition will be in place. If theres No Deal, planes could be grounded, ports jammed up and customs checks thrown into chaos at pm.  December : If theres a deal, this is when the transition period - which continues pretty much all the EU rules we have now - is supposed to end. But talk has been floated of extending this by a few months. After December : If theres still no deal, under current plans a backstop would kick in. This could keep the UK tied to EU customs rules, until a proper agreement is reached, in exchange for keeping the Northern Ireland border open. For more information read our guide to whats happening with the Brexit talks and  ways No Deal Brexit will affect your le. The EUs plans have left the UK in an unusual deadlock. UK officials are racing to try and block the EUs proposal before Brexit on  March . If that doesnt happen, there are fears the change could happen during a Brexit transition period - forcing the UK to go along with the rest of the EU against its will. But questions remain over what happensthe change comes after a transition period, orthere is no transition period at all. Ms Tolhurst said: We are still hopeful we will be able to block this proposal.

Brussels unveiled the key policy as part of contingency planstheres no deal on  March . Officials had discussed making the UK a third country - forcing travellers to pay  Eurosfor an entry permit. But EC vice president Frans Timmermans today said that will be waived - as long as the UK gives EU citizens the same privilege. He told a Tuesday press conference in Strasbourg: On visas we propose to amend the visa regulation to allow UK nationals to be exempt from any visa requirement for short stays in the EU once EU law stops applying to the UK.But of course an important point: this is entirely conditional on the UK also doing the same thing for EU nationals, reciprocating.  A document released by the Commission says the rules would apply to Britons travelling to Schengen Area nations, which includes all western European EU members states and eastern ones including Poland, Latvia, Lithuania, Estonia, the Czech Republic and Slovakia. It would apply to trips of up to  days within any -day period, starting from March  in the event of a no-deal Brexit and from the end of any transition perioda deal is achieved. Adding to Mr Timmermans remarks, it also says: This proposal is entirely conditional upon the UK also granting reciprocal and non-discriminatory visa-free travel for all EU Member States, in line with the principle of visa reciprocity.  The UK government has declared its intention not to require a visa from citizens of the EU Member States for shorts stays for the purposes of tourism and business. EU rules on non-EU nationals travelling to the EU, such as those on border control, would of course apply to UK citizens once they are no longer EU citizens. The Commission urged the European Parliament and Council to back the change quickly so that it can be adopted in good time before  March .

title: film maker lured flat before
story: NewsFilm maker lured to flat before robbers poured ammonia down his throatVictims Courtney Raymond, , and Jordan Dubois, , arrived at a flat in Ilford, east London, where they planned to make a video for a song called CreepyShareByAbigail OLeary:,  NOV NewsWilliam Deo denies all charges against him "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA film maker was allegedly lured to a flat before robbers poured ammonia down his throat - leaving him in two-week coma, a court heard. Courtney Raymond, , and Jordan Dubois, , arrived at a flat in Ilford, east London, where they planned to make a video for a song called Creepy. They were greeted by -year-old Makayla Hajaig who said her singer sister Stafia was inside putting make-up on, jurors heard. After entering the house, Raymond and Dubois were allegedly pounced on by Adam Badejo, , William Deo, , said Nathan Rasiah, prosecuting. Mr Raymond was knocked to the floor and a third man, wearing a balaclava, poured ammonia down his throat, Snaresbrook Crown Court heard. Mr Rasiah said: Stafia exists but has no involvement in this case. Her identity was used for the purpose of setting the ambush. On  May, Hajaig used an Instagram account to contact Courtney Raymond.  Raymond and Dubois were later sent a song by email with the subject Creepy MP. Mr Rasiah said: On  June the defendants arrived together. The men went into the property and laid in wait. Courtney Raymond and Jordan Dubois arrived at the scene and were met by a young woman. She told them it was her sister who contacted them, and she was upstairs getting her make-up done. The three of them went into the property together with Jordan Dubois carrying his equipment in an Adidas rucksack. Makayla Hajaig led them in saying the flat belonged to her sisters family. Mr Raymond recalls two or three men running at them from upstairs and a large figure with a balaclava coming towards him with a bottle, said Mr Rasiah.  They both recall him squirting a liquid in their faces. Mr Raymond believed it was acid, but it was in fact ammonia. Mr Raymond and Mr Dubois were told to hand over their bags containing cameras and lighting equipment worth over pound,, jurors heard. Mr Raymond was punched in the stomach his knees gave way, but he was forced to get up and open his mouth, said the prosecutor. One of the figures poured the liquid down his throat and it started to burn. Mr Raymond and Mr Dubois managed to get away and staggered to the home of neighbour Damien Butler who began pouring water over their faces. Both Courtney Raymond and Jordan Dubois were taken to hospital around about :pm, said Mr Rasiah. Mr Raymond was seen to in the AE department at Queens Hospital and he was sedated and placed in a medically induced coma and he remained in intensive care for some  days until  June.

The group says Toby Carverys Unicorn Freakshake - containing an alarming  teaspoons of sugar and , calories - topped a list of milkshakes served at restaurants and fast food outlets in the UK. Five Guys banana and chocolate milkshake had  teaspoons of sugar and , calories, the campaigners claim. title: george charlotte louis christmas presents
story: NewsWhy George, Charlotte and Louis wont open presents on Christmas DayThe young royals wont be running down the stairs on Christmas morning to seeFather Christmas has beenShareCommentsBySteve MyallNicola OakleyHead of AudienceZoe Forsey:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsThe Cambridges after the christening of Prince Louis "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailChristmas Day is a very dferent occasionyoure a royal. While the majority of us will spend the day stuffing our faces, lounging on the sofa and arguing with relatives over Monopoly, its a much more formal occasion for the royals. And there is one tradition that is very dferent in the Royal Household: opening presents. Instead of running downstairs on Christmas morning, theres a good chance Prince George and Princess Charlotte wont actually open their presents on the big day. As millions of children across the UK make wrapping paper mountains across their living room carpets, George, Charlotte and Louis family will be preparing to go to a church service at Sandringham.  The entire royal family traditionally spends Christmas and New Year at Sandringham, the Queens country estate in Norfolk. It hasnt always been that way. When the Queens children - Charles, Anne, Andrew and Edward - were small, Christmases were spent at Windsor Castle. But in  when the castle was being rewired, the family uprooted to Sandringham and the festive season has been spent there ever since. The royal family normally open their presents on Christmas Eve, a legacy of the German heritage of the monarchy. Former royal chef Darren McGrady said: The royals are of German descent so they weave in German traditions to their celebrations. After afternoon tea, they open gts on Christmas Eve, as is the German tradition.  So the Cambridge children will have already opened their presents before most other British kids. Its possible that the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge will give them some presents to open on Christmas Day, too - or theyll receive some from extended family. But Prince William might want to carry on the tradition hes grown up with of opening gts on Christmas Eve. And, of course, present giving in the royal household isnt as simple as writing a gt tag and leaving it under the tree. Presents are placed on a white linen-covered trestle table in the red drawing room, with cards marking exactly where the piles of gts should be put. Tapes mark out sections for each family member and any of the Queens household who is on duty for the weekend.  Prince Louis will be celebrating his first Christmas this year as he was born in April. Prince George was delighted last Christmas after Santa got him the one present he really wanted. The prince, then four years old, requested a toy police car from Father Christmas. His dad, Prince William, delivered the handwritten letter in person on a trip to Helsinki in November. William explained there was much excitement when George got his toy car at Sandringham. And as for the adults in the royal family, what do you buy the people who have everything   Well, it turns out the royals tend to buy each other jokey presents rather than serious gts. Princess Anne once gave Charles a white leather loo seat, William gave Philip a gumboot-shaped soap, and Harry bought his grandmother a shower cap emblazoned with the words “Aint le a bitch ” And one Christmas, Kate gave Prince Harry, a plastic grow your own girlfriend kit.
